Award.AwardTitle: SUNY LSAMP 2010 Bridge to the Doctorate: BD Site University at Buffalo

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The State University of New York (SUNY) Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (SUNY LSAMP), under the leadership of SUNY-Stony Brook, will support 12 additional post-baccalaureate students duirng the 2010-2012 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) program at the University of Buffalo. This program builds on previous program efforts that have not only significantly added to the graduate enrollment and masters and doctoral degrees to students from underreprested minority (UREP) populations but have also led to important changes in the culture and practice of STEM education in ways that not only help UREP students but all graduate STEM students.

The project adds to current efforts by SUNY LSAMP to build research capacity in STEM education in the area of graduate education. The lessons learned from the study of the Bridge to the Doctorate Program will be put into the context of broader issues of systemic change and disseminated to a broad national audience.

Using the lessons learned from this project, the alliance expects to continue to develop and refine strategies that will increase the recruitment and retention of graduate students and further diversify graduate education departments. The strategy has the potenital to increase the number of UREP STEM students who successfully complete doctoral degrees in STEM disciplines and make changes in STEM departmental culture and practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The State University of New York Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (SUNY LSAMP) Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) cohort at the University at Buffalo (UB) was fully enrolled with students in eight science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors. One student is currently completing his masters’ degree. The rest of the students have either received STEM masters’ degrees or are in STEM doctoral programs. Students who received masters’ degrees are employed in positions in the high technology sector. Some examples are: Laboratory Data Manager at the Frontier Science and Technology Research Foundation, Research Scientist at the New York State Department of Health and Engineer Estimator at Mass Electric Construction. BD students average GPA was an impressive 3.69. Students presented their research at conferences and were authors on published articles in both national and international venues. One student won an NSF IGERT Fellowship. 

Program objectives that were achieved were:

Providing a comprehensive services that monitor student progress

Building a strong BD community of STEM Scholars 

Developing BD students’ academic and professional skills 

Instilling a sense of altruism in UB BD graduate students to serve as mentors and instructors for the STEM community 

Collaborating with  other  NSF  and  state  and  federal programs  to  make  the  best  use  of program resources by integrating BD students into an existing network of programs and activities

Assessing the  success  of  program  services  through external  evaluation and  developing modified activities or  interventions  based  on  the  results
of  this  evaluation 

Ensuring that BD students have the tools necessary to successfully gain admission to doctoral programs at the conclusion of BD

Preparing BD  students  to  apply  for  NSF  and  other  graduate fellowships 

Establishing relationships with  STEM  departments , the UB Graduate School
and  the  New York State Underrepresented Fellowship Program to develop plans  to  provide a formal pathway to PhD programs

Working with  STEM  departments  to  provide  academic support  where needed  to  help students through  doctoral  study   

Developing an effective system for tracking students after they  leave BD

Promoting  systemic change  in  graduate STEM  policy  and  practices  in ways that  will increase  the  success  of individual  students 

Using resources  from  multiple  sources  to  examine broad  issues  related  to  graduate  education for underrepresented STEM students
